page.title: 12BEE-KEEPING
page.content: Near Bluegate Hall is Mr. Ridgewell's apiary, which is situated in a small copse which is reached by a field track. There are 6 hives containing an average of 7O,OOO bees and 4 smaller hives which house 4O,OOO bees which are used for rearing queens. The bees are from an Italian stock and came originally from Northern Italy. These bees are calmer and more productive than the native black bee. The honey that Mr. Ridgewell collects each year from his hives is usually from rape, field bean and wild rose. The queens are reared by grafting queen bee cells and removing the original queen from the hive. This encourages the workers to feed the new queen bee cells on the necessary food, royal jelly. The queen bees are sold with 12 workers to start new colonies for other bee keepers.
